TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ToolStripProgressBar extends System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripControlHost

Docs.summary: Represents a Windows progress bar control contained in a .

remarks.format:
## Remarks <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> is the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBar> optimized for hosting in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip>. A subset of the hosted control's properties and events are exposed at the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> level, but the underlying <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBar> control is fully accessible through the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.ProgressBar%2A> property.
A <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control visually indicates the progress of a lengthy operation. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control displays a bar that fills in from left to right with the system highlight color as an operation progresses.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control can only be oriented horizontally.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control is typically used when an application performs tasks such as copying files or printing documents. Users of an application might consider an application unresponsive if there is no visual cue. Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> to notify the user that the application is performing a lengthy task and that the application is still responding.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> properties define the range of values to represent the progress of a task. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property is typically set to a value of zero, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property is typically set to a value indicating the completion of a task. For example, to display the progress properly when copying a group of files, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property could be set to the total number of files to be copied. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property represents the progress that the application has made toward completing the operation. Because the bar displayed in the control is a collection of blocks, the value displayed by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> only approximates the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property's current value. Based on the size of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar>, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property determines when to display the next block.
There are a number of ways to modify the value displayed by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> other than changing the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property directly. You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property to specify a specific value to increment the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property by, and then call the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method to increment the value. To vary the increment value, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method and specify a value by which to increment the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property.
<xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> replaces the older <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ProgressBar> control, which is nevertheless retained for backward compatibility.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> that calculates a sequence of Fibonacci numbers.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar/CS/form1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar/VB/form1.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Increment(int32 value) cil managed

Docs.param: The amount by which to increment the progress bar's current position.
Docs.summary: Advances the current position of the progress bar by the specified amount.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method enables you to increment the value of the progress bar by a specific amount. This method of incrementing the progress bar is similar to using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property specifies the current position of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar>. If, after calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is greater than the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property remains at the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property. If, after calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method with a negative value specified in the `value` parameter, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is less than the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property remains at the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value representing the delay between each display update, in milliseconds.
Docs.value: An integer representing the delay, in milliseconds.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.MarqueeAnimationSpeed%2A> property gets or sets the delay of display update. Therefore, as you decrease the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.MarqueeAnimationSpeed%2A> property, the speed of the animation increases.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int Maximum { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.Maximum : int with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the upper bound of the range that is defined for this .
Docs.value: An integer representing the upper bound of the range. The default is 100.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property specifies the upper limit of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property. When the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property is changed, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control is redrawn to reflect the new range of the control. When the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is equal to the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property, the progress bar is completely filled.
You can use this property to specify a value that the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property must be set to (by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property or using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> methods) to indicate that an operation is complete. For example, you can set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property to the total number of files in a file copy operation. Each time a file is copied, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property can be increased by one until the total number of files is copied. At that point, the progress bar would be completely filled.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates a use of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> that calculates a sequence of Fibonacci numbers. This code example is part of a larger example that provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> class.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property int Minimum { int get(); void set(int value); };
member this.Minimum : int with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the lower bound of the range that is defined for this .
Docs.value: An integer representing the lower bound of the range. The default is 0.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property specifies the lower limit of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property. When the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property is changed, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> control is redrawn to reflect the new range of the control. When the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is equal to the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property, the progress bar is empty. To change the value of the progress bar, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method, or set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property directly.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates a use of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> that calculates a sequence of Fibonacci numbers. This code example is part of a larger example that provided for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.OnRightToLeftLayoutChanged%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's method so that registered delegates receive the event.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void PerformStep() cil managed

Docs.summary: Advances the current position of the progress bar by the amount of the property.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method increments the value of the progress bar by the amount specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property. You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property to specify the amount that each completed task in an operation changes the value of the progress bar. For example, if you are copying a group of files, you might want to set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property to 1 and the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property to the total number of files to copy. When each file is copied, you can call the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method to increment the progress bar by the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Step%2A> property. If you want to have more flexible control of the value of the progress bar, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Increment%2A> method or set the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property directly.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property specifies the current position of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar>. If, after calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is greater than the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property remains at the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Maximum%2A> property. If, after calling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.PerformStep%2A> method with a negative value specified in the `value` parameter, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property is less than the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Value%2A> property remains at the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.Minimum%2A> property.

member this.RightToLeftLayout : bool with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the layout is right-to-left or left-to-right when the property is set to .
Docs.value: to turn on mirroring and lay out control from right to left when the property is set to ; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.RightToLeftLayout%2A> property to control the layout of international applications in which the language is written from right to left. When the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.RightToLeftLayout%2A> property is `true`, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft> property is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft.Yes>, mirroring will be enabled on the Windows form and control placement and text will be from right to left.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Custom Event RightToLeftLayoutChanged As EventHandler

Docs.summary: Occurs when the value of the property changes.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.RightToLeftLayoutChanged> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> named `ToolStripProgressBar1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar.RightToLeftLayoutChanged> event.
